revision.text:
{{Redirect|Numbered Account|the racehorse|Numbered Account (horse)}}[[File:Zürich Paradeplatz, Credit Suisse.jpg|thumb|261x261px|Many [[Banking in Switzerland|banks in Switzerland]] and other [[Offshore financial centre|off-shore financial centers]], offer the usage of numbered bank accounts for an extra degree of [[Bank secrecy|banking secrecy]].]]'''Numbered bank accounts''' are [[bank account|bank accounts]] where the identity of the holder is replaced with a multi-digit number known only to the client and select private bankers.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/fancy-yourself-a-numbered-swiss-bank-account-heres-how-you-can-get-one/articleshow/44979525.cms|title=Fancy yourself a numbered Swiss Bank account? Here's how you can get one|last=|first=|date=October 30, 2013|work=The Economic Times|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://money.howstuffworks.com/personal-finance/banking/swiss-bank-account5.htm|title=How Swiss Bank Accounts Work|last=Obringer|first=Lee Ann|date=June 8, 2011|work=HowStuffWorks|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en}}</ref> Although these accounts do add another layer of [[Bank secrecy|banking secrecy]], they are not completely anonymous as the name of the client is still recorded by the bank and subject to limited, warranted disclosure.<ref name=":2" /><!-- The lack of citations is purposeful. Refer to Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Lead section#Citations for more information. Wikipedia allows there to be little to no citations in the lead area if it is cited within the main body. If there is something in the lede not cited in the main part drop a {{not found in body}} citation needed tag and it will be addressed. -->
During the 1910s, bankers from Switzerland created numbered bank accounts to add a layer of [[anonymity]] for European clients seeking to avoid paying [[World War I]] taxes.<ref name=":43">{{Cite book|url=|title=The Fall of UBS: The Forces that Brought Down Switzerland's Biggest Bank|last=Schütz|first=Dirk|date=2000|publisher=Pyramid Media Group|year=|isbn=9780944188200|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> With the passage of the [[Federal Act on Banks and Savings Banks|Swiss Banking Law of 1932]], the practice proliferated across the [[Banking in Switzerland|banking industry in Switzerland]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.swiss-privacy.com/numbered-bank-account.html|title=Swiss-Privacy.com {{!}} Numbered bank account|last=|first=|date=|website=www.swiss-privacy.com|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> Some Swiss banks supplement the number with a [[code name]] such as "[[St. Louis Cardinals|Cardinal]]",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/06/business/stefan-buck-tax-evasion.html|title=A Swiss Banker Helped Americans Dodge Taxes. Was It a Crime?|last=Enrich|first=David|date=January 6, 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 20, 2018|language=en|quote=Several hunkered down in Switzerland, which refused to extradite its citizens to the United States for actions that weren’t illegal in Switzerland. None had actually gone on trial.}}</ref> "[[Octopussy]]"<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/20/business/global/20ubs.html|title=Under Agreement, UBS to Give Up 4,450 Names|last=Browning|first=Lynnley|date=August 19, 2009|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 15, 2018|language=en}}</ref> or "[[Cello]]"<ref name=":02" /> that identifies the client, alternatively.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/study-guide/series-10/chapter-34/chapter-3/numbered-accounts/|title=Numbered Bank Accounts - Series 10 {{!}} Investopedia|last=|first=|date=November 12, 2014|work=Investopedia|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US|quote=A broker dealer, at the request of the customer, may open an account that is simply identified by a number or a symbol, as long as there is a statement signed by the customer attesting to the ownership of the account.}}</ref> However, to open this type of account in Switzerland, clients must pass a multi-stage clearance procedure and prove to the bank the lawful origins of their assets.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/26182063|title=How To Open A Swiss Bank Account|last=Koba|first=Mark|date=August 20, 2008|work=CNBC|access-date=May 12, 2018}}</ref> Banking institutions that have adopted this practice in [[Europe]], [[Asia]], and [[Americas|the Americas]] also require clients to undergo stringent vetting and provide the identity of the beneficial owner.<ref name=":1" /> The usage of fake names to open these accounts is prohibited in Switzerland, the [[European Union]], the [[United States]], and other [[Offshore financial centre|off-shore financial centers]].<ref name=":1" />
Many sovereign state governments have outlawed the usage of these accounts as they commonly associated with a desire by the account holder to either minimize governmental scrutiny or avoid taxation.<ref name=":1" /> Most regulations governing the usage of numbered bank accounts require that the holder signs a document and undergoes a [[background check]] that confirms who they are and a connection to the account.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.offshore-manual.com/SwissNumbered.html|title=Offshore Manual: Swiss Numbered Bank Account|last=|first=|date=|website=www.offshore-manual.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> Despite the regulations, numbered bank accounts by their very nature are more private than normal bank accounts. In Switzerland, for example, bankers are outlawed from disclosing whether or not an account is numbered to any governmental agency unless proof of deliberate fraud is established, not merely the non-reporting of assets in order to avoid taxation.<ref name=":0" /><!-- Keep article on the shorter side as much of the hyperlinks connect to other related article, see WP:O. -->
==See Also== * [[Banking in Switzerland]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=40em}}
[[Category:Bank account]] [[Category:Privacy]] [[Category:Security]]

revision.text:
The '''Omni Commons''' are a group of thirteen collectives in [[San Francisco]]'s [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] devoted to [[Do it yourself|DIY]] and community education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2016/10/09/five-years-after-occupy-oakland-still-fighting-for-the-99-percent/|title=5 Years After Occupy Oakland, Still Fighting for the 99 Percent|last=Stelzer|first=Andrew|date=2016-10-09|work=|newspaper=KQED News|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-10|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/CultureSpyBlog/archives/2014/03/19/newly-formed-multi-disciplinary-collective-omni-oakland-eyes-former-omni-building|title=Newly Formed Multi-Disciplinary Collective Omni Oakland Eyes Former Omni Building|last=Mark|first=Julian|date=|work=|newspaper=[[East Bay Express]]|access-date=2016-10-10|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://oaklandlocal.com/2014/11/oaklands-omni-commons/|title=Oakland's Omni Commons space is where it's at - Oakland Local|last=Anderson|first=Eric James|date=2014-11-18|work=|newspaper=Oakland Local|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-10|via=}}</ref> It traces its inception to the [[Occupy movement]], specifically [[Occupy Oakland]], and was founded in 2014 on the principles of "community, positive creation and radical inclusion".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thebolditalic.com/oakland-s-tech-boom-will-be-very-different-from-san-francisco-s-the-bold-italic-san-francisco-a27dd6f92475#.g5f7un6c2|title=Oakland’s Tech Boom Will Be Very Different from San Francisco’s — The Bold Italic — San Francisco|last=Bethencourt|first=Ryan|date=2015-12-10|newspaper=The Bold Italic|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2015/01/02/spirit-of-occupy-lives-on-in-new-super-collective/|title=Spirit of Occupy lives on in new super-collective|last=|first=|date=2 January 2015|website=|publisher=[[The Mercury News]]|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref>
== Building == Constructed in 1933, the building at 4799 Shattuck Ave in [[Oakland]] was conceived as the meeting hall for Club L'Igure, the Italian garbagemen's social club. The 22,000 sq ft [[Victorian architectural style]] building hosts a 4,000 sq ft ballroom, a large foyer, a Disco room complete with illuminated floors, a children's play room, a large industrial kitchen, and many more spaces of varying sizes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://omnicommons.org/wiki/Building|title=Omni Commons Wiki-- Building|website=omnicommons.org/mediaWiki|last=various authors|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> The building is available to the community for hosting a wide variety of events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://omnicommons.org/calendar/locations/ballroom/|title=Ballroom events listing|access-date=24 July 2017}}</ref>
== Collectives == The Commons currently consist of 13 member collectives ranging from activist groups to [[hackerspace]]s,<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://omnicommons.org/index.html#about|title=About Us|last=|first=|date=|website=omnicommons.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref> each of which have a representative in the Omni Oakland Collective's Delegate Council, the decision making body of the group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://omnicommons.org/wiki/Founding_Document|title=Founding Document|last=|first=|date=|website=omnicommons.org|publisher=Omni Commons|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref> Collectives include:
=== Counter Culture Labs === A [[Do-it-yourself biology|biohacker]] and [[citizen science]] lab in Oakland’s [[Temescal, Oakland, California|Temescal]] neighborhood, [[Counter Culture Labs]] serves as a community [[laboratory]] and hackerspace for people from any skill level.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2016/04/08/weekender-counterculture-labs/|title=Back and Forth: Counter Culture Labs|last=Harhen|first=Nora|date=2016-04-08|website=[[The Daily Californian]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref>
=== sudo room === An open-membership [[hackerspace]] in Oakland with an emphasis on community [[outreach]] and service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://liveworkoakland.com/listings/sudo-room/|title=Sudo Room|last=|first=|date=|website=Live Work Oakland|publisher=|access-date=10 October 2016}}</ref> Active projects hosted by Sudo Room include a weekly hardware hack night, regular programming hangouts, and [[People's Open Network]], a [[community wireless network]] being developed by [[Sudo Mesh]], in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sudoroom.org/calendar/|website=Sudoroom.org|title=Sudo Room Calendar of Events|access-date=24 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://peoplesopen.net/blog/network-map/|website=Peoplesopen.net blog|title=Peoplesopen.net Network Map|last=Martin|first=Will|access-date=24 July 2017}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Double Union]] * [[Noisebridge]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * https://omnicommons.org/ Omni Commons website
[[Category:Occupy Oakland]] [[Category:Organizations based in Oakland, California]] [[Category:Hackerspaces in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:DIY culture]] [[Category:Public laboratories]] [[Category:Public commons]]

revision.text:
{{Contains Khoekhoe text}} The '''Red Nation''' ({{lang-naq|'''Khaiǁkhaun'''}}) is the main subtribe of the [[Nama people]] in [[Namibia]] and the oldest Nama group speaking [[Khoekhoegowab]], the language often called Damara/Nama.
The main settlement of the Red Nation is [[Hoachanas]], a small settlement in southern central Namibia, today part of the [[Hardap Region]].<ref name="Republikein"/>
==History== ===Pre–colonial period===
The word ''Khaiǁkhaun'' means "great defender" in Khoekhoe, from ǁkhau, "defend". There is no agreement as to where the name ''Red Nation'' originated from. [[Heinrich Vedder]] claims that the Khaiǁkhaun called themselves ǀAwa-khoi, "red people", whereas [[Klaus Dierks]] declares that the Europeans later nicknamed the tribe ''Red Nation''. In any case, the attribution is a reference to their slightly reddish face color.<ref name="Republikein">{{cite news |url=http://www.republikein.com.na/politiek-en-nasionale/the-historical-role-of-the-nama-nation.45136.php |title=The historical role of the Nama nation |last=Dierks |first=Klaus |date=3 December 2004 |work=[[Die Republikein]]}}</ref>{{sfn|Vedder|1997|pp=126f}}
The first [[Tribal chief|Kaptein]] of the Khaiǁkhaun was ǂHâb who unified most of the Nama clans at the end of the 17th century. After ǂHâb's death in 1710 the [[ǁKhauǀgoan]] (Swartbooi Nama) and the [[ǂKharoǃoan]] (Keetmanshoop Nama) were the first Nama groups to leave the union<ref name="KDHeroesday">{{cite web |url=http://www.klausdierks.com/Chronology/Hoachanas_01.12.2004.htm |title=Hoachanas Heroes Day, 2004 |last=Dierks |first=Klaus |authorlink=Klaus Dierks |publisher=klausdierks.com |accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref> and to settle at [[Rehoboth, Namibia|Rehoboth]] and [[Keetmanshoop]], respectively. Later other groups split from this union one by one and settled at different places in central and southern Namibia,<ref name="Malan">{{cite book |last=Malan |first=Johan S |title=Die Völker Namibias |trans-title=The Tribes of Namibia |year=1998 |publisher=Klaus Hess |location=Windhoek, Göttingen |language=German |pages=120–125}}</ref> but the Red Nation is still regarded as the main Nama faction.<ref name="Republikein"/>
With [[Manasse ǃNoreseb]]{{'s}} ascent to chieftaincy in 1880, hostilities started between the Red Nation and other Nama clans. [[Hendrik Witbooi (Namaqua chief)|Hendrik Witbooi]], leader of the [[ǀKhowesin]] (Witbooi Nama) was an archenemy of Manasse. His superiority in power forced the Red Nation into alliances with other Nama factions such as the [[ǁOgain]] (Groot Doden) and the [[ǀHaiǀkhauan]] (Berseba Orlam), but also the [[Ovaherero]], and later the [[German Empire|Imperial]] colonial administration of [[German South-West Africa]].<ref name="NE">{{cite news |title=Kaptein Manasse !Noreseb: The political strategist and gallant freedom fighter against German colonialism |url=http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=41390 |last=Shiremo |first=Shampapi |date=28 October 2011 |newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]]}}</ref>
Witbooi attacked Hoachanas several times and broke the resistance of the Khaiǁkhaun. He installed a rival chief, ǃHoeb ǁOasemab ([[Fritz Lazarus ǁOaseb]]) and confiscated the land of the Red Nation. The German protection treaty did not help, the Germans never had the intention to help single parties within the same tribe. [[Heinrich Vedder]] opined that Witbooi's plan was to defeat the Nama tribes one by one, lease the land back to them after he conquered it, and gain the position of a Nama Paramount Chief in the process.{{sfn|Vedder|1997|pp=645–647}}
===German colonial period=== When the [[Herero and Namaqua Genocide|Herero and Nama War]] broke out in which the Germans attacked the indigenous Herero and Nama in [[German South-West Africa]], Manasse ǃNoreseb and Hendrik Witbooi ceased their hostilities and fought together against the ''[[Schutztruppe]]'' ("protection force", the units deployed to the German colonies). The Red Nation under Manasse, with only 100 armed men, took over the defense of the central eastern area of [[Aranos]], [[Leonardville, Namibia|Leonardville]], [[Aminuis]], and Hoachanas.<ref name="NE"/>
The German Empire's ''Schutztruppe'' defeated both the Nama and the Herero during this war. Manasse ǃNoreseb and Hendrik Witbooi died in 1905, survivors were detained in [[concentration camp]]s, much the same way as the British had set up camps for forced labour in their [[Union of South Africa|colony of South Africa]] during the [[Anglo-Boer War]] of 1899–1902. Thousands of people, including women and children, died in these concentration camps from illness, neglect, and malnutrition,<ref name=KDW/> leading to a [[Herero and Namaqua genocide|genocide of the Herero and Nama peoples]].<ref>[[David Olusoga|Olusoga, David]] and Erichsen, Casper W (2010). ''The Kaiser's Holocaust. Germany's Forgotten Genocide and the Colonial Roots of Nazism''. Faber and Faber. {{ISBN|978-0-571-23141-6}}</ref><ref> {{Cite book |title=The Holocaust: Theoretical Readings |last=Levi |first=Neil |author2=Rothberg, Michael |year=2003 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |isbn=0-8135-3353-8 |page=465}}</ref>
After the defeat in the war, Namas were displaced all over the country, and even deported to the German colonies of [[Togoland]] and [[Kamerun]].<ref name=KDW>{{cite web |url=http://www.klausdierks.com/Biographies/Biographies_W.htm |last=Dierks |first=Klaus |authorlink=Klaus Dierks |title=Biographies of Namibian Personalities, W |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> The ethnical structures of the Nama people were destroyed; the Red Nation only got a new chief in 1922.<ref name="NE"/>
==Traditional leaders== The following people have been chiefs of the Red Nation since the foundation of that clan in 1695:<ref name="KDHeroesday"/> #ǂHâb (1695–1710) #ǁKhomab ǂHâmab (1710–1725) #ǁKhaub gaib ǁKhomab (1725–1740) #ǂÔ-ǁnâib ǁKhaumab (1740–1755) #ǀHanab ǂÔǁnâimab (1755–1770) #ǃGaob ǀHanamab (1770–1800) #Gaméb ǃGaomab (1800–1814) #Tsawúb Gamab (1814–1824) #!Na-khom Gamab (1824–1840) #ǁOaseb !Na-khomab (1840–1867) #ǂGoraxab ǀOasib (Barnabas, 1867–1871) #Gôbeb ǂGoraxab (Petrus, 1871–1880) #Manasse !Noreseb Gamab (1880–1905) #ǃHoëb ǁOaseb (Fritz Lazarus, 1922–1936) #Noach Tsai-Tsaib (1936–1948) #Matheus Kooper (1948–1986) #Petrus Simon Moses Kooper (since 1988)
==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}}
===Literature=== * {{cite book |last=Vedder |first=Heinrich |authorlink=Heinrich Vedder |title=Das alte Südwestafrika. Südwestafrikas Geschichte bis zum Tode Mahareros 1890 |trans-title=South West Africa in early times; Being the story of South West Africa up to the date of Maharero's death in 1890. |language=German |year=1997 |edition=7th |publisher=Namibia Scientific Society |location=Windhoek |isbn=0-949995-33-9 |ref=harv}}
[[Category:Ethnic groups in Namibia]] [[Category:Nama people]]

revision.text:
The '''Santa Monica Track Club''' was formed in 1972 by Joe Douglas as a post-collegiate track club.<ref>http://www.flotrack.org/videos/coverage/view_video/234884-2009-outdoor-season-on-flotrack/186994-joe-douglas-founder-of-santa-monica-track-club FloTrack interview</ref> By the 1980s, the team came to be a major player in worldwide [[Track and field athletics|Track and Field]] competition, with team members setting numerous World and National records. The membership list reads like a ''[[Who's Who]]'' of Olympic athletes and the SMTC logo became a recognizable icon on the uniforms of those elite athletes.
==History== In its first year of existence, [[Puerto Rico at the 1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Olympian]] from [[Puerto Rico]], Willie Rios joined the club and qualified to run in the [[1972 Summer Olympics]]. In 1974, member Reid Harter set the first [http://www.usatf.org/statistics/records/view.asp?division=american&location=road&age=open&sport=LDR American Record] in the road 30 Kilometre run. By 1976, three team members qualified for the [[1976 Summer Olympics]].<ref>http://www.santamonicatrackclub.org/about-us.html Santa Monica Track Club</ref>
In 1979, a young [[Carl Lewis]], then known as a top level High School long jumper, joined the club for competitions beyond his collegiate career at the [[University of Houston]]. Lewis went on to be the dominant force in sprinting and long jump for the next decade. Coached in the off season by his collegiate coach [[Tom Tellez]], other elite sprinters were attracted to the club, including [[Carol Lewis]], Carl's sister and University of Houston teammates [[Joe DeLoach]], [[Leroy Burrell]] and [[Kirk Baptiste]]. The club developed an impressive record of Olympic and World Championships, limited in many situations because teammates were the closest competition at the highest level. Lewis and Burrell exchanged the prestigious World Record in the [[100 metres]] four times.
Four members of the club, [[Michael Marsh (athlete)|Michael Marsh]], [[Leroy Burrell]], [[Floyd Heard]] and [[Carl Lewis]], representing the Santa Monica Track Club tied the [[Men's 4 × 100 metres relay world record progression#Records since 1977|world record in the 4x100 meters relay]] at the [[Herculis]] meet in [[Monaco]]. The record lasted for four days until it was surpassed by a team representing the USA that consisted of three of the SMTC members, with [[Dennis Mitchell]] replacing Heard. The same four members set the World Record in the 4 x 200 metre relay, set at the [[Mt. SAC Relays]] in 1994.<ref>http://www.iaaf.org/statistics/toplists/inout=O/age=n/season=0/sex=M/all=y/legal=A/disc=4X2/detail.html IAAF 4 x 200 Relay list</ref> That record lasted over 20 years until it was surpassed by .05 by a team from Jamaica at the [[2014 IAAF World Relays – Men's 4 × 200 metres relay|2014 IAAF World Relays]]. Also [[Kevin Young (athlete)|Kevin Young]]'s World Record in the [[400 metre hurdles]] set in winning the [[Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Summer Olympics]] still stands.<ref>http://www.iaaf.org/statistics/toplists/inout=o/age=n/season=0/sex=M/all=y/legal=A/disc=400H/detail.html IAAF 400 metre hurdles list</ref>
The club was elected into the [[Mt. SAC Relays]] Hall of Fame in 2011.<ref>http://www.mtsacrelays.com/fame.html</ref>
==Foundation== The club is funded through the Santa Monica Track Club Foundation, founded by [[Ed Stotsenberg]] (who had the personalized license plate SMTC 1), an early [[Masters athletics|Masters]] runner who joined the club in the mid-1970s and became its president.<ref>http://www.letsrun.com/forum/flat_read.php?board=1&thread=1500001&id=1504182 Lets Run</ref><ref>http://www.santamonicatrackclub.com/main_foundation.htm Santa Monica Track Club</ref>
==Membership==
* [[Carl Lewis]] - 9 Olympic Gold Medals, 1 Silver, 8 World Championship Gold Medals, 3 time World Record holder [[100 metres]] * [[Leroy Burrell]] - 1 Olympic Gold Medal, 2 World Championship Gold Medals, 2 time World Record holder [[100 metres]] * [[Kevin Young (athlete)|Kevin Young]] - 1 Olympic Gold Medal, 1 World Championship Gold Medal, current World Record holder [[400 metre hurdles]] * [[Steve Lewis (athlete)|Steve Lewis]] - 3 Olympic Gold Medals, 1 Silver * [[Michael Marsh (athlete)|Mike Marsh]]- 2 Olympic Gold Medals, 1 Silver, 1 World Championship Gold Medal * [[Danny Everett]] - 1 Olympic Gold Medal, 1 Bronze, 1 World Championship Gold Medal * [[Joe DeLoach]] - 1 Olympic Gold Medal * [[Michelle Finn-Burrell]] - 1 Olympic Gold Medal * [[LaMont Smith]] - 1 Olympic Gold medal * [[Kirk Baptiste]] - 1 Olympic medal * [[Johnny Gray]] - 1 Olympic medal, current United States record [[800 metres]] * [[Earl Jones (athlete)|Earl Jones]] - 1 Olympic medal * [[Carol Lewis]] - 1 World Championship Bronze medal * [[David Mack (police officer)|David Mack]] * [[Floyd Heard]] * [[André Action Jackson]] * [[Cletus Clark]] * [[Mark Witherspoon]] * [[United States at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Todd Harbour]] * [[Prince Mumba]] * [[George Kersh]] * [[Lewis Johnson]] * [[Bayano Kamani]] * [[Delisa Walton-Floyd]] * [[Jenny Spangler]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.santamonicatrackclub.org Official Santa Monica Track Club website]
[[Category:Running clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Track and field clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Sports in Santa Monica, California]] [[Category:Sports teams in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in the United States]] [[Category:Athletics clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Track and field in California]] [[Category:1972 establishments in California]] [[Category:Organizations based in Santa Monica, California]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2011}}
'''Short-term business statistics''' (STS) are [[economic statistics]] published by [[Eurostat]], the [[European Commission]]'s statistical office. They cover each of the [[member states of the European Union]], and provide aggregated results for the euro area and the EU. Short-term business statistics provide information on the economic development of four major domains: industry, construction, retail trade, and other services. These domains are defined in relation to a classification of economic activities, the NACE Rev.2 ([[Statistical Classification of Economic Activities in the European Community]], second revision).
For the four domains the following variables are reported (most on a monthly, some on a quarterly basis):
* Industry: Production, turnover (domestic and non-domestic), new orders (domestic and non-domestic), number of persons employed, hours worked, gross wages and salaries, output prices (domestic and non-domestic), import prices. * Construction: Production (total, of buildings and of civil engineering), number of persons employed, hours worked, gross wages and salaries, construction costs (material costs, wage costs), construction permits. * Retail trade and repair: Turnover, retail trade volume, number of persons employed. * Other services: Turnover, number of persons employed, output prices.
The legal authority<ref>[http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/statistics_explained/index.php/Short-term_business_statistics_-_legal_base Eurostat - Statistics Explained: Short-term business statistics - legal base]</ref> for the European short-term business statistics is Regulation EC No 1165/98,<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31998R1165:EN:HTML Council Regulation (EC) No 1165/98 of 19 May 1998 concerning short-term statistics, ''Official Journal of the European Communities''. L 162, 1998-06-05, pp. 1-15.]</ref> as amended by Regulation EC No 1158/2005,<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2005:191:0001:0015:EN:PDF "Regulation (EC) No 1158/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2005 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1165/98 concerning short-term statistics"], ''Official Journal of the European Communities''. L 191, 2005-07-22, pp. 1-15.</ref> and further implementing and amending regulations.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page/portal/short_term_business_statistics/introduction/ Eurostat - Short-term business statistics] * [http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/statistics_explained/index.php/Category:Short-term_business_statistics Eurostat - Statistics Explained: all articles on short-term business statistics]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Short-Term Business Statistics}} [[Category:European Commission]] [[Category:Economic data]] [[Category:Economy of the European Union]] [[Category:Year of establishment missing]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group= Singaporean Canadians |population = '''2,850''' (2016)<ref>{{citation|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=PR&Code1=01&Geo2=PR&Code2=01&Data=Count&SearchText=Canada&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=Ethnic%20origin&TABID=1|title=Ethnic origin population |publisher=Statistics Canada|series=Census 2016|accessdate=July 4, 2018}}</ref> |image= |caption = <small>[[Devan Nair]]</small> |langs= [[Canadian English]]{{·}} [[Mandarin Chinese]]{{·}} [[Malay language|Malay]]{{·}} [[Tamil language|Tamil]] {{·}} [[Canadian French]] |popplace= [[Toronto]]{{·}} [[Vancouver]]{{·}} [[Edmonton]] |rels= [[Buddhism]]{{·}} [[Islam]]{{·}} [[Hinduism]]{{·}} [[Taoism]]{{·}} [[Christianity]] |related= [[Chinese Canadian]]{{·}} [[Indo-Canadians]] }} There is a small community of '''Singaporeans in Canada''', consisting largely of expatriate professionals and immigrants from [[Singapore]] and their families as well as [[international students]] and [[Canadians|Canadian]] citizens of [[Singaporean]] descent.
==Migration history== During the 1970s, arrivals to Canada from Singapore numbered less than 100 per year while in the following decade, immigrants born in Singapore averaged between 200 and 400. In the years 1989–91, arrivals from Singapore approached 1,000.<ref>[http://multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/m3/2 : Multicultural Canada - Malaysians-Singaporeans/Migration and Settlement] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120712190848/http://multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/m3/2 |date=2012-07-12 }}</ref>
Many Singaporeans are employed by Canadian companies or in the public sector, including universities. They also figure prominently among medical doctors, accountants, engineers, and architects. Approximately one-third are self-employed and have entered Canada under that category or as entrepreneurs. Most of their businesses are urban-based and often have a highly technical focus, such as computers or chemical and engineering products. Most Singaporeans in Canada tend to retain their citizenship in anticipation of possible return.<ref>[http://multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/m3/3 : Multicultural Canada - Malaysians-Singaporeans/Economic Life] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120713080511/http://multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/m3/3 |date=2012-07-13 }}</ref>
Between 1987 and 1991, some 1,500 to 1,800 Singaporean students were living in Canada.
==Notable Singaporeans in Canada== * [[Chloe Ing]], figure skater * [[Thea Lim]], writer * [[Devan Nair]], former [[President of Singapore]] * [[Jonathan Seet]], Canadian singer-songwriter * [[Goh Poh Seng]], Singaporean dramatist, novelist and poet * [[Steph Song]], actress
==See also== {{Portal|Canada|Singapore}} * [[Singaporean American]] * [[Chinese Canadian]] * [[Tamil Canadian]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Asian Canadians}} {{People of Canada}} {{Singaporeans abroad and their descendants}}

revision.comment: /* Involuntary subordinate strategy */copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Meanwhile → Meanwhile,
revision.text:
{{underlinked|date=May 2018}}
'''Social rank theory''' provides an evolutionary [[paradigm]] that locates affiliative and ranking structures at the core of many psychological disorders. In this context, displays of submission signal to dominant individuals that subordinate group members are not a threat to their rank within the [[Social stratification|social hierarchy]]. This helps to achieve [[Group cohesiveness|social cohesion]]. According to social rank theory, anxiety and depression are natural experiences that are common to all mammalian species, and it is the pathological exaggeration of anxiety and depression that contributes to psychological disorders.
== Social rank in group living == Three hundred million years ago [[proto-mammals]] individually competed for resources such as food, territory, and sexual partners. Over time, some species began to live in groups, which brought the evolutionary advantages of increased protection from predators and adversaries, increased access to resources, and better reproductive success.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aL40CwAAQBAJ&pg=PR6&lpg=PR6&dq=ISBN:+978-1-138-82463-8+(pbk)&source=bl&ots=pRuHHU5cYi&sig=pe4Up-JqkX0iyD9XGdQQuH033FA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE15zXrO7aAhVniVQKHbWiDRkQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=ISBN%3A%20978-1-138-82463-8%20(pbk)&f=false|title=Evolutionary psychiatry: a new beginning|last=Stevens|first=Anthony; Price, John|publisher=Routledge|others=|year=2016|isbn=9781138824638|edition=Classic|location=New York|pages=|oclc=935679992}}</ref> With the adoption of group living emerged two psychological systems which functioned to preserve the new social order: a social rank system and a safety system.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gilbert|first=P.|last2=Cheung|first2=M. S-P.|last3=Grandfield|first3=T.|last4=Campey|first4=F.|last5=Irons|first5=C.|date=2003|title=Recall of threat and submissiveness in childhood: development of a new scale and its relationship with depression, social comparison and shame|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/cpp.359|journal=Clinical Psychology & Psychotherapy|language=en|volume=10|issue=2|pages=108–115|doi=10.1002/cpp.359|issn=1063-3995}}</ref>
Upon adopting group living practices, competition between individuals shifted from struggles for territory to social rank, as dominant individuals have better access to limited resources than their subordinates.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tse|first=Wai S.|last2=Wu|first2=Jayne|last3=Poon|first3=Kai-Chung|date=2011-05|title=Motivation for achievement as perceived resource value in social rank theory of depression: A structural equation modeling analysis|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0191886911000250|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=50|issue=7|pages=1034–1038|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.01.019|issn=0191-8869}}</ref> Dominant positions can also equate to high status as well as the authority to administer punishments and rewards within the group.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Weisman|first=Ora|last2=Aderka|first2=Idan M.|last3=Marom|first3=Sofi|last4=Hermesh|first4=Haggai|last5=Gilboa-Schechtman|first5=Eva|date=2011-06|title=Social rank and affiliation in social anxiety disorder|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0005796711000829|journal=Behaviour Research and Therapy|volume=49|issue=6-7|pages=399–405|doi=10.1016/j.brat.2011.03.010|issn=0005-7967}}</ref> Ranking benefits the group through the implementation of a social framework that lowers the overall energy expenditure of the group where conspecifics are competing for the same resources.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/2614371|title=Sociobiology and behavior|last=P.|first=Barash, David|date=1977|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=0444990291|location=New York|oclc=2614371}}</ref> For instance, the acknowledgement of differences in rank curbs aggressive behavior.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/852790506|title=Primate Social Systems|last=M.|first=Dunbar, Robin I.|date=1988|publisher=Springer US|isbn=9781468466966|location=Boston, MA|oclc=852790506}}</ref> Ranking also functions as a channel through which social control and resources are allocated. Thus, the purpose of the social rank system is to remain attuned the social hierarchy to better compete for rank, and consequently expand resource acquisition.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
Conversely, the safety system views the social world not as a competitive space, but instead as a cooperative space where others may extend reassurances and assistance. Thus, the safety system searches for opportunities to cooperate and connect with potential allies.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Evaluations of sameness and difference are crucial to making [[Ingroups and outgroups|in-group/out-group]] distinctions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/12237533|title=Social Psychology|last=Brown|first=Roger|date=|publisher=Free Press|year=1986|isbn=9780029083000|edition=2nd|location=New York|pages=|oclc=12237533}}</ref> One’s level of belonging within the group is often based on the ability to conform to group mores and standards and has been found to be a predictor of group acceptance, popularity, and rank.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=Jack C.|last2=Giammarino|first2=Mary|last3=Parad|first3=Harry W.|date=1986|title=Social status in small groups: Individualgroup similarity and the social "misfit."|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/0022-3514.50.3.523|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|language=en|volume=50|issue=3|pages=523–536|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.50.3.523|issn=1939-1315}}</ref> It has been suggested that the ingroup/outgroup distinctions may have emerged from kin selection, as hunter-gatherer groups were often genetically related.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sociobiology and Mental Disorder: A New View|last=Wenegrat|first=B.|publisher=Addison-Wesley|year=1984|isbn=|location=California|pages=}}</ref> Within humans, the sense of group belonging has evolved to become fundamental to physical and mental health and security, having important implications for self-esteem and self-identity.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Depression-Evolution-Powerlessness-Routledge-Editions/dp/1138953156|title=Depression: the evolution of powerlessness|last=Gilbert|first=Paul|date=|publisher=Routledge|year=2016|isbn=1317189426|location=New York|pages=|oclc=956521476}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Abrams|first=D.|last2=Wetherell|first2=M.|last3=Cochrane|first3=S.|last4=Hogg|first4=M. A.|last5=Turner|first5=J. C.|date=June 1990|title=Knowing what to think by knowing who you are: self-categorization and the nature of norm formation, conformity and group polarization|journal=The British Journal of Social Psychology|volume=29 ( Pt 2)|pages=97–119|issn=0144-6665|pmid=2372667}}</ref> Because networks and alliances have become so important in humans, our internal evaluative algorithms, for making both judgements of rank and belonging have become linked.<ref name=":3" />
== Social ranking behavior == Studies demonstrate that primates adhere two main forms of group living characterized by opposing interactional styles: agonic and hedonic.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/911386423|title=Social fabrics of the mind|last=Chance|first=Michael R.A.|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Ltd.|others=|year=1988|isbn=|location=Hove|pages=|oclc=}}</ref> The agonic mode of interaction is typical of hierarchical societies, in which group members concentrate on defending against threats to status. Agonic behavior is focused around aggression as well as the inhibition of aggression, often through either submission or appeasement. On the other hand, the hedonic mode of interaction is characteristic of [[Egalitarianism|egalitarian societies]], where cooperative and affiliative behavior is common. Hedonic behavior is more affectional and is distinguished by reassurance and reconciliation. Both modes of interaction can be found in all societies, to varying degrees.
=== Agonistic interactions ===
==== Ritualistic agonistic behavior ==== Agonistic competition spans back as far as 300 million years, and thus is deeply ingrained into the genome.<ref name=":0" /> Extensive observational evidence of reptiles and birds reveal that when they compete for breeding territory, individuals engage in a specific manner of interactional display, known as ritualistic agonistic behavior (RAB).<ref name=":3" /> Opponents confront one another and display various power signals which may include standing tall, maintaining eye contact, or puffing themselves up.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Foundations of Ethology|last=Lorenz|first=Konrad|publisher=Springer Verlag|year=1981|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=MacLean|first=P. D.|date=1977|title=The triune brain in conflict|journal=Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics|volume=28|issue=1-4|pages=207–220|doi=10.1159/000287065|issn=0033-3190|pmid=416456}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=MacLean|first=P. D.|date=April 1985|title=Brain evolution relating to family, play, and the separation call|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=42|issue=4|pages=405–417|issn=0003-990X|pmid=3977559}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Behavioural Biology of Aggression|last=Archer|first=John|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1988|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=}}</ref> This type of behavior can also be found in humans, especially in the context of a physical contest.
RAB functions as a means of evaluating the strength, fighting capability, and resource holding potential (RHP) of one’s opponent.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Parker|first=G. A.|date=September 1974|title=Assessment strategy and the evolution of fighting behaviour|journal=Journal of Theoretical Biology|volume=47|issue=1|pages=223–243|issn=0022-5193|pmid=4477626}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Behavioral Ecology: An Evolutionary Approach|last=Parker|first=G.A.|publisher=Blackwell|year=1984|isbn=|editor-last=Krebs|editor-first=John R.|location=Oxford|pages=|chapter=Evolutionary Strategies|editor-last2=Davies|editor-first2=Nick B.}}</ref> If one determines that their own RHP is inferior to that of their adversary and will likely lose the altercation, they may take flight and escape unscathed. On the other hand, if one determines that their own RHP is stronger than that of their opponent, they are free to initiate the altercation. Thus, an accurate internal evaluative algorithm is crucial not only for evading or prolonging potentially fatal fights, but also for provoking winning situations which may improve one’s social rank.<ref name=":3" />
==== Involuntary subordinate strategy ==== After assessing one’s opponent, territorial species usually react with either a flight or flight response. However, in a "blocked escape" scenario, where territory is limited or escape is impossible, this pattern diverges.<ref name=":3" /> Upon losing dominance, defeated individuals undergo a change in physical demeanor known as the yielding subroutine of RAB or the involuntary subordinate strategy (ISS).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Price|first=John S.|last2=Sloman|first2=Leon|date=|title=Depression as yielding behaviour: an animal model based upon Schjelderup-Ebbe’s pecking order|url=|journal=Ethology and Sociobiology|volume=8|pages=85s–98s|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Price|first=J.|last2=Sloman|first2=L.|last3=Gardner|first3=R.|last4=Gilbert|first4=P.|last5=Rohde|first5=P.|date=March 1994|title=The social competition hypothesis of depression|journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry|volume=164|issue=3|pages=309–315|issn=0007-1250|pmid=8199784}}</ref> For example, an early study of farmyard fowls found that despite an absence of physical injury, defeated birds seemed to be paralyzed. Furthermore, with their wings and head lowered to the ground, the birds seemed to experience depressive mood. Similarly, another study demonstrated that defeated lizards lost their characteristic bright colors, then died shortly after.<ref name=":4" /> Given the proximity to and dependency on conspecifics, group-living animals are perpetually faced with blocked escape scenarios, as a flight response to in-group confrontation would result in both diminished breeding chances as well as heightened threat of predation.<ref name=":3" />
ISS impedes the capability of the subordinate individual to attempt a comeback and signals to their opponent that they are not longer a threat. Thus, ISS is adaptive in that it ensures that when the subordinate individual goes down, they stay down. Meanwhile, it also indicates to the dominant individual that their opponent has truly yielded, so altercation need not continue.<ref name=":0" />
==== Submissive behaviors ==== Among group-living species, regular fighting is prevented through the inhibition and control of RAB. Within these groups, subordinates are largely responsible for acknowledging dominant individuals through overt acts of submission. Individuals who believe themselves to be in a subordinate role must be able to prevent the provocation of an attack by a dominant conspecific, or, if an attack is elicited, swiftly terminate the attack. Subordinate individuals are able to accomplish this through submissive involuntary body language, which can include screaming, sideways glances, the fear grin, lowering the eyes, crouching to appear smaller, etc.<ref name=":3" />
Another avenue through which subordinates communicate their submission is through the mobilization of internal inhibition. Like the submissive postures and gestures listed above, internal inhibition is involuntary. This inhibitory process is characterized by the suppression of exploratory behavior and an inability to take initiative, both of which may be the consequences of attempts to avoid the aggressive attention of dominant individuals.<ref name=":3" /> Internal inhibition stimulates high states of arousal, and thus, increased levels of tension in subordinates.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/852792281|title=Stress, Health, and the Social Environment : a Sociobiologic Approach to Medicine|last=J.P.|first=Henry|last2=Stephens|first2=P.M.|date=|publisher=Springer Verlag|others=|year=1977|isbn=9781461263654|location=New York, NY|pages=|oclc=852792281}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sapolsky|first=R. M.|date=November 1989|title=Hypercortisolism among socially subordinate wild baboons originates at the CNS level|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=46|issue=11|pages=1047–1051|issn=0003-990X|pmid=2554841}}</ref> Internal inhibition can also lead to the loss of energy, depressed mood, retarded movements, reduced information processing capacity, sleep disturbance, poor appetite, loss of confidence, all of which are characteristic of depression. In submitting to dominant individuals and constraining their own reproductive and resource seeking behaviors, subordinates regulate levels of aggression within the group.<ref name=":3" /> It is in this context that external and internal inhibitive behaviors are adaptive.
=== Hedonistic interactions === Within the last ten million years, hedonistic forms of social competition have emerged. In hedonistic interactions individuals actively attract conspecifics in order to elevate social status.<ref name=":0" /> Status is achieved through the demonstration of constructive qualities such as beauty, intelligence, talents, and special abilities.<ref name=":3" /> Social approval of these qualities raises self-esteem, while disapproval can result in lowered self-esteem, loss of status, and reduced attractiveness to potential mates.<ref name=":0" /> In other words, with the knowledge that one is valued by conspecifics signals reassurance and orients individuals towards affiliation as opposed to agonistic interactions. Hedonistic interactions are also characterized by the formation of alliances and coalitions, which offer another avenue through which to improve status. In building networks of alliances, individuals dedicate a lot of effort towards ensuring that one’s self-presentation properly conforms to group mores and standards. As a result, a great deal of social life entails the seeking group approval which acts to both confirm rank and impart a sense of belonging.<ref name=":3" />
==== Mate selection ==== Social dominance by means of attractiveness has been shown to be essential in determining reproductive success.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Power, Dominance and Nonverbal Behavior|last=Shively|first=Carol|publisher=Springer-Verlag|year=1985|isbn=|editor-last=Ellyson|editor-first=Steve L.|location=New York|pages=|chapter=The Evolution of Dominance Hierarchies in Nonhuman Primates|editor-last2=Dovidio|editor-first2=John F.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Social Evolution|last=Trivers|first=Robert|publisher=Benjamin/Cummings|year=1985|isbn=|location=California|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Human Evolution: An Introduction for the Behavioural Sciences|last=Richards|first=Graham|publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul|year=1987|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Primate Social Systems|last=Dunbar|first=Robin Ian MacDonald|publisher=Croom Helm|year=1988|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref> For instance, it is not strength and aggression, but attractiveness that forms the basis of human mate selection.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buss|first=David M.|date=|title=Sex differences in human mate preference: Evolutionary hypotheses tested in 37 cultures|url=|journal=Brain and Behavioral Sciences|volume=12|pages=1–49|via=}}</ref> Human females tend to be drawn towards mates who are able to protect and invest in children. Thus, for women, attractiveness is associated with status. On the other hand, human males are often drawn towards biologically health mates which is manifested by natural beauty and youth.<ref name=":3" />
==== Social investment ==== The dominance hierarchy is also an attention hierarchy in that well integrated individuals evoke and secure higher levels of positive social attention than less integrated individuals. Not only does positive attention lower defensive arousal, but positive attention from higher ranking individuals heightens mood. Social attention also functions as a means through which individuals can elicit investment from others. Conspecifics may be coaxed into investing in socially attractive individuals, who can then access more resources, form more alliances, secure mates, and affirm group membership.<ref name=":3" /> The measure of one’s ability to secure attention and elicit investment is known as social attention holding potential (SAHP). With elevated social status, leadership roles, and access to more resources, those with high SAHP benefit from increased evolutionary fitness. On the other hand, individuals with low levels of SAHP tend to display the submissive behaviors characteristic of ISS such as inhibition, withdrawal, and lack of confidence.<ref name=":0" /> Estimates of rank and social attractiveness can be internalized. These internal estimates have implications for one’s biological state. For instance, depressive brain state patterns may reflect either a primitive defeat-like state which involves loss of feeling and social withdrawal; or a more submissive pattern with various efforts to elicit investment from others; or some combination of the two.<ref name=":3" />
== Psychological application == Social rank theory predicts that success within agonistic and hedonistic interactions can have the following effects on human [[psychopathology]]:<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" |+ !Interaction Type !Result on Psychopathology |- |Successful Affiliation |Social adjustment and mental health |- |Failure in Affiliation |[[Schizoid personality disorder]], [[Schizotypal personality disorder|schizotypal]] or [[Schizophreniform disorder|schizophreniform]] illness and an introverted, inner-directed mode of personality adjustment |- |Submission |Low self-esteem, feelings of [[shame]] and [[humiliation]], dependent personality disorder, [[anxiety]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[wikt:Special:Search/masochism|masochism]], and a liability to be victimized or abused |- |Dominance |High self-esteem, [[Type a personality|Type A personality]], [[hypomania]], [[Sadistic personality disorder|sadism]], and a liability to victimize and abuse others |}
== See also == * [[Evolutionary approaches to depression|Evolutionary Approaches to Depression]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Group processes|Cohesiveness]] [[Category:Social groups]] [[Category:Social psychology]]

{{italic title}} '''''The Resurrection of Hungary: A Parallel for Ireland''''' was a book published by [[Arthur Griffith]] in 1904 in which he outlined his ideas for an [[Anglo-Irish]] [[dual monarchy]]. He proposed that the former kingdoms which had created the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] in 1801, namely, the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and the [[Kingdom of Ireland]], return to the pre-1801 arrangement whereby they had two governments but a shared king. The policy, which was modelled on [[Hungary]]'s achievement of equal status with [[Austria]] under the [[Habsburg]] emperor/king, became the basis for the policy of Griffith's new [[Sinn Féin]] party. He proposed a dual monarchy, similar to the equivalent of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, formed under the [[Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867|Compromise of 1867]].
Griffith summed up his ideas in the book by comparing the relative status of Hungary vis-à-vis Austria and Ireland vis-à-vis Great Britain:
{{quote|The Hungarians resorted to a manly policy of [[Passive Resistance (Hungary)|passive resistance]] and non-recognition of Austria’s right to rule – the Irish resorted to parliamentarianism, implying recognition of an English right to rule this country. And one nation today is rich, powerful and able to defy her conqueror, while the other is poor, weak and more tightly held in the conqueror’s grasp.<ref>[http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/index.asp?locID=462&docID=2373 Griffith's book] quoted by [[Taoiseach]] [[Bertie Ahern]] in 2005.</ref>}}
He advocated a policy of [[abstentionism]] from the institutions of the United Kingdom and a return to the ''[[Constitution of 1782]]'' agreed between the British government and the [[Parliament of Ireland]] in 1782.
Griffith called his new party, Sinn Féin, a "King, Lords and Commons Party".<ref>[[ibid]].</ref> The ''Anglo-Irish Empire'' idea, though strongly associated with Griffith, was not uniquely his creation. As early as the mid-1880s Lord Salisbury, leader of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] had contemplated using the 1867 Austro-Hungarian example as a model for a reformed relationship between Britain and Ireland.<ref>[http://www.irishdemocrat.co.uk/reviews/griffiths-legacy/ Peter Berresford Ellis in ''The Irish Democrat'' in 2003.]</ref>
From 1917 the party while maintaining its commitment to abstentionism, abandoned Griffith's proposal for having the British monarch on the Irish throne as [[King of Ireland]]. Instead it was split between republicans (those associated with the [[Easter Rising]] in 1916 and who had subsequently joined Sinn Féin) who advocated the creation of a new republic with an elected head of state, and those who advocated the creation of an Irish monarchy, albeit now with a monarch chosen from any [[royal house]] but the [[House of Windsor]].
The concept was ridiculed by the nationalist commentator DP Moran, who called its supporters the "Green Hungarian Band".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kelly|first1=Joseph|title=Our Joyce: From Outcast to Icon|date=1998|publisher=University of Texas Press|page=45|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=Zn-r5DEF_68C&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=%22green+hungarian+band%22&source=bl&ots=TUtxPddsvI&sig=EYapbLLZWicT0TOj9GLU_hMYX54&hl=en&sa=X&ei=K7pMVZnqCcKtsgHmz4GIDg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22green%20hungarian%20band%22&f=false|accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref>
In 1917 the party's ''[[Ard Fheis]]'' adopted a motion committing the party to establishing a republic before holding a referendum on whether to install a monarchy or not, once the monarch chosen was not from the House of Windsor.<ref>Ard Fheis, October 1917.</ref> The party later committed itself unambiguously to supporting a republic.
Given its introduction of the concept of abstentionism, and its formative role in the appearance of Sinn Féin, ''The Resurrection of Hungary'' was one of the most influential texts in 20th-century Irish history.

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Turks in Belgium | image = [[File:Yunus Emre Mosque, Genk.jpg|250px]] | caption = 'Turkish day' outside the 'Yunus Emre Camii' (mosque) in [[Genk]], Belgium. | population = 200,000–250,000<ref>{{Harvnb|King Baudouin Foundation|2008|loc=5}}</ref><ref name="RTBF">{{cite web|author=Olay|title=Cinquantième anniversaire de l'immigration turque en Belgique |url=http://www.rtbf.be/info/regions/detail_cinquantieme-anniversaire-de-l-immigration-turque-en-belgique?id=7551483|work=RTBF|date=2012-02-10|accessdate=2012-10-17}}</ref><ref name="Olay">{{cite web|author=Olay|title=Belçika’da Türk adaylar yarışacak|url=http://www.olay.com.tr/haber/dunya/belcikada-turk-adaylar-yarisacak-125172.html|work=Olay|date=2012-10-13|accessdate=2012-10-17}}</ref> <small>1.8%-2.3% of Belgian population</small> | popplace = {{hlist|[[Antwerp]]|[[Brussels]]|[[Genk]]|[[Ghent]]}} | langs = {{hlist|[[Turkish language|Turkish]] | [[Dutch language|Dutch]] | [[French language|French]]}} | rels = [[Sunni Islam]], [[Shia Islam]] }} [[File:Belçika'da Türk Günü.jpg|thumb|''Turkish day'' at the [[Grand Place]] (2006)]] [[File:Brussels by night.jpg|thumb|Turkish flags in the [[Brussels]] town of [[Sint-Joost-ten-Node]]]]
'''Turks in Belgium''' or '''Belgian Turks''' refers to [[Turkish people]] who have immigrated to [[Belgium]]. However, the term may also refer to Belgian-born persons who have Turkish parents or who have a Turkish ancestral background.
== History ==
[[Turkish people|Turkish]] migration to [[Belgium]] began in the 1960s when Belgium was actively encouraging immigration to meet its employment needs in an era of rapid economic expansion.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1996|loc=66}}.</ref> These immigrants were welcomed as "[[guest workers]]" when [[Turkey]] signed a bilateral agreement with Belgium in July 1964.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kasaba|2008|loc=192}}.</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Cohen|1995|loc=279}}.</ref> As mainly unskilled labourers, Turkish immigrants hoped to make a fortune in a short time and then return to Turkey. The majority of Turkish migrants arrived from the rural regions of [[Central Anatolia Region|central Anatolian provinces]], particularly from [[Afyon]], [[Eskisehir]] and [[Kayseri]].<ref name="Wets 2006 loc=93">{{Harvnb|Wets|2006|loc=93}}.</ref> Many settled in the industrialised areas and later brought families when Belgium attempted to resolve the growing problem of low population by encouraging family reunions.<ref name="Moutsou 2006 loc=123">{{Harvnb|Moutsou|2006|loc=123}}.</ref>
By the 1970s the phenomenon of immigrants arriving in Belgium with a [[tourist visa]] started; most came from [[Afyon]], especially from the town of [[Emirdağ]].<ref name="Gailly 1997 loc=147">{{Harvnb|Gailly|1997|loc=147}}.</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Akgündüz|2008|loc=92}}.</ref> Upon arrival they looked for work and tried to legalise their status as labourers. The presence of these tourists created a [[black market]] labour force so that on two occasions the government had to legalise their status. Once they obtained the status of "guest workers" they could bring in their family.<ref name="Gailly 1997 loc=148">{{Harvnb|Gailly|1997|loc=148}}.</ref>
By the 1980s, immigration to Belgium for economic reasons was forbidden by law. The only legal way to take up residence in Belgium was by [[family reunification]], which was only applicable to members of the [[nuclear family]] of guest workers or by marrying someone who was a [[Belgian nationality law|Belgian citizen]]. Another possible motive for coming to Belgium was to apply for the status of [[asylum-seeker]] upon arrival. Turkish asylum seekers came from all over Turkey, with some belonging to minority groups in the country (such as [[Kurds]]). However, other asylum seekers included ethnic Turks from [[Eastern Europe]] (such as [[Bulgarian Turks]] and [[Macedonian Turks]]).<ref name="Gailly 1997 loc=148"/>
Since the entry of [[Bulgaria]] into the European Union, thousands of [[Bulgarian Turks]], among whom many were already working in Belgium as undocumented foreigners, have established themselves under the status of independent workers, i.e. officially minor associates in small firms, mostly in the building and cleaning sector. They've brought with them their spouses and children, thus beginning to make Belgium their new home, some children are indeed born in Belgium, even when their parents were or are still undocumented. There were officially 1,957 Bulgarian-born persons living in Belgium in 2001, 4,807 in 2006.<ref>{{Citation|title=Migrations et populations issues de l'immigration en Belgique - Rapport statistique et démographique 2008|editor=Schoonvaere, Quentin|publisher=Centre for Equal Opportunities and Opposition to Racism|year=2009|url=http://www.diversite.be/diversiteit/files/File/studies/2009/migratie/Rapport_demographie_2008_-_complet.pdf|language=French}}</ref>
== Demographics == {{see also|Demographics of Belgium}} {{Update|section|date=December 2017}} {| cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" rules="all" style="float:left; width:250px; margin:1em; background:#fff; border:2px solid #aaa; font-size:100%;" |- style="background:#ddd;" | colspan="8" style="text-align:center;"| Naturalisation of Turkish citizens:<ref>{{Harvnb|Kaya|Kentel|2007|loc=20}}.</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|2008|loc=356}}</ref> |- style="background:#f0f0f0; text-align:center;" ! Year ! Population ! Year ! Population |- | 1990 || 706 || 1999 || 4,402 |- | 1991 || 1,020 || 2000 || 17,282 |- | 1992 || 4,044 || 2001 || 14,401 |- | 1993 || 3,415 || 2002 || 7,805 |- | 1994 || 6,263 || 2003 || 5,186 |- | 1995 || 6,925 || 2004 || 4,467 |- | 1996 || 7,066 || 2005 || 3,602 |- | 1997 || 7,835 || 2006 || 3,204 |- | 1998 || 6,932 || 2007 || 3,039 |}
The census of 1970 counted 21,000 Turks; in the part-census of 1977 this figure had risen to 60,000. For the next few years, family reunifications continued to raise the totals and by 1981 there were 64,000 Turks. Although this growth was slowing down, it did continue to grow to 72,000 Turks by 1985.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nielsen|2004|loc=70}}.</ref> By 1996, there were 81,744 Turks in Belgium, 26% of whom lived in [[Brussels]] and 50% in [[Flanders]]-particularly in [[Antwerp]] and [[Ghent]].<ref name="Moutsou 2006 loc=123"/> In 1993, some 88,269 people with Turkish nationality were registered in Belgium, however by 1999, this dropped to 70,701 Turkish nationals because a substantial part of the population adopted the Belgian nationality.<ref name="Timmerman 2004 loc=144">{{Harvnb|Timmerman|2004|loc=144}}.</ref>
Turks still continue to migrate to Belgium in the hope of building a better future; many lured by social and economic security.<ref name="Timmerman & Van der Heyden 2005 loc=94">{{Harvnb|Timmerman|Van der Heyden|2005|loc=94}}</ref>
The majority of Turks living in Belgium originate from the region of [[Emirdağ]] although there are also many Turks from [[Sivas]] who found their way to Belgium.<ref name="Timmerman & Van der Heyden 2005 loc=91">{{Harvnb|Timmerman|Van der Heyden|2005|loc=91}}</ref> Some 49.8% live in the [[Flemish region]], 25.2% in [[Wallonia]], and 25% in [[Brussels]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Blommaert|Verschueren|1998|loc=43}}</ref> Turks from the same region in Turkey also tend to congregate not only in the same cities but also in the same quarters.<ref>{{Harvnb|Gailly|1997|loc=149}}.</ref>
The majority of Turks live in the [[Schaarbeek]] commune.<ref>{{Harvnb|State|2004|loc=279}}.</ref> The Chaussee De Haecht street is heavily populated with Turkish immigrants,<ref>{{Harvnb|Koutroubas|Vloeberghs|Yanasmayan|2009|loc=73}}</ref> with its pizzerias, pastry shops, cafes, and barbers, is reminiscent of a Turkish street. According to the Turkish Consulate in [[Antwerp]], the number of Turks there is about 75,000, and there are 115 Turkish associations just in Antwerp. There are an addition 82 Turkish associations in [[Brussels]].
== Religion == {{see also|Religion in Belgium|Islam in Belgium}}
The majority of Turks are Sunni [[Muslims]]<ref>{{Harvnb|Levinson|1998|loc=13-14}}.</ref> Several Turkish Sunni groupings are active in Belgium, most notably [[Milli Görüş]] (''Fédération islamique belge''), the [[Süleyman Hilmi Tunahan|Süleymancis]] (''Union des Centres culturels islamiques de Belgique'') and the [[Said Nursî|Nurcus]] . As in other countries, there is also an official Sunni [[Presidency of Religious Affairs|Diyanet]] (''Fondation religieuse islamique turque de Belgique''), which controls most mosques and a majority of the affiliations to the repatriation funerary insurance.
Another Turkish Muslim community present in Belgium is the [[Alevism|Alevi]] one, with several associations in Brussels, the ''Centre culturel turc pour le respect de la personne humaine - Erenler'' (Turkish cultural centre for the respect of the human being - Erenler), officially registered in 1994, founded by Alevis from the village of Karacalar, near Emirdag, led by their traditional spirituel leader (''dede'') from the Şahbaz family, and the more progressive ''Centre socioculturel alévi de Bruxelles'', officially registered in 2003 by 14 founding members, 4 of whom were born in [[Elbistan]], 3 in Belgium, 2 in [[:tr:Gücük, Elbistan|Gücük]] (near Elbistan), the rest in [[Adıyaman]], Inis, [[Tunceli]], [[Soğucak]] and {{Interlanguage link multi|Sün|tr|3=Sünköy, Elazığ}}),<ref>{{Citation|date=November 13, 2003|title=Centre socioculturel alévi de Bruxelles|journal=[[Belgian Official Journal|Moniteur belge]]|publisher=Kingdom of Belgium|location=Brussels|language=French|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv_pdf/2003/11/13/03119240.pdf|postscript=.}}</ref> [[Charleroi]] (''Centre culturel alévi de Charleroi'', officially registered in 1999 by 9 founding members, 6 of whom had the dual Turkish-Belgian citizenship),<ref>{{Citation|date=January 21, 1999|title=Centre culturel alévi de Charleroi|journal=[[Belgian Official Journal|Moniteur belge]]|publisher=Kingdom of Belgium|location=Brussels|language=French|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/vzw/vzwf2.htm|postscript=.}}</ref> [[Antwerp]] (''Alevietische Kultureel Centrum Antwerpen''), [[Liège]] (from 2002 till 2004 ''Liège Alevi Kultur Dernegi - Association culturelle Alévi de Liège'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv_pdf/2004/03/30/04050732.pdf |title=''Liège Alevi Kultur Dernegi - Association culturelle Alévi de Liège'' |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-01-24}}</ref> since 2005 ''Foyer culturel alévi de Liège'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv_pdf/2005/10/27/05153556.pdf |title=''Foyer culturel alévi de Liège'' |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-01-24}}</ref> and the [[Limburg (Belgium)|Limburg province]] (''Samenwerking Limburgse Alevieten'', officially registered in 1990). There is also a Federation of the Belgian Alevi Associations, ''Belçika Alevi Birlikleri Federasyonu'', since 2008 ''Fédération unions des Alévis en Belgique - Belçika Alevi Birlikleri Federasyonu'' (FUAB-BABF),<ref>''[http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv_pdf/2008/02/28/08033120.pdf Fédération unions des Alévis en Belgique - Belçika Alevi Birlikleri Federasyonu]''</ref> created in 2003, based in Antwerp, then in Brussels in 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv_pdf/2006/01/06/06006146.pdf |title=Fédération unions des Alévis en Belgique - Belçika Alevi Birlikleri Federasyonu |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-01-24}}</ref> and grouping the ''Alevietische Kultureel Centrum Antwerpen'', the ''Centre culturel alévi de Charleroi'' and the ''Samenwerking Limburgse Alevieten''.
== Organisations and associations == There are dozens of Turkish associations in Belgium, most are grouped into federations, either linked to the Turkish government ([[Presidency of Religious Affairs|Diyanet]]) and embassy or to various Turkish religious and political movements, [[Milli Görüş]] (''Fédération islamique belge''), the [[Said Nursî|Nurcus]], the [[Süleyman Hilmi Tunahan|Süleymancis]] (''Union des Centres islamiques de Belgique''), the [[Grey Wolves (organization)|Grey Wolves]] (''Verbond der Turkse Verenigingen in België'', ''Belçika Ülkücü Türk Dernekleri Federasyon/Belçika Türk Federasyonu'') etc.
== Political participation == At the federal level, several deputies and senators have been elected or coopted to the [[Belgian Chamber of Representatives]] and [[Belgian Senate|Senate]]. Among them, the [[Socialistische Partij Anders|Flemish Socialists]] [[Cemal Çavdarlı]] (deputy in 2003-2007) and {{Interlanguage link multi|Fatma Pehlivan|nl}} (senator in 2001-2007, and again in 2009-2010), the [[Groen!|Flemish Ecologists]] [[Meryem Kaçar]] (senator in 1999-2003) and [[Meyrem Almaci|Meyrem Almacı]] (deputy since 2007, reelected in 2010), the [[Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams|Flemish Christian Democrat]] {{Interlanguage link multi|Hilâl Yalçin|nl}} (deputy in 2007-2010), the [[New-Flemish Alliance|N-VA]] attorney [[Zuhal Demir]] (deputy since June 2010; [[Antwerp (district)|Antwerp district]] mayor since January 2013) and [[Socialist Party (francophone Belgium)|French-speaking Socialist]] {{Interlanguage link multi|Özlem Özen|fr}} (deputy since June 2010). Kaçar, Cavdarlı and Pehlivan are [[Ghent]] residents, Almacı and Demir are Antwerp residents Yalçın comes from the Limburg province and Ozen from the Walloon province of Hainaut.
There are also Turkish-Belgian members of the regional parliaments, one of them, [[Emir Kir]] ([[Socialist Party (francophone Belgium)|French-speaking Socialist Party]]), became an underminister in the [[Politics and Government of the Brussels-Capital Region|Brussels regional government]] in [[Belgian regional elections, 2004|2004]], and again in [[Belgian regional elections, 2009|2009]], as Secretary for Public Sanitation and Monument Conservation.
A dozen Turkish-Belgian municipal councillors became ''échevin'' or ''schepen'' (alderman) after the [[Belgian provincial and municipal elections, 2006|2006 municipal elections]], mostly in Flanders or the Brussels Region, plus a few in Wallonia.
== Music == Turks have also contributed to music in Belgium, recently [[Hadise]] daughter of a family from [[Sivas]] was in the pop music world in Belgium. Hadise made a name for herself in 2003 in the “Idool” song contest sponsored by VTM, the largest Belgian broadcaster. Her songs “[[Stir Me Up]]” and her album “[[Milk Chocolate Girl]]” were on top of the charts for a long time.
==Notable people== {{see also|List of Belgian Turks}} <gallery class="center"> File:Hadise 2006.jpg|[[Hadise Açıkgöz]], Singer File:Zeynep Sever.jpg|[[Zeynep Sever]], [[Miss Belgium]] 2009 File:Önder Turacı.jpg|[[Önder Turacı]], footballer File:Murat Akın (1).jpg|{{Interlanguage link multi|Murat Akin|nl}}, footballer </gallery>
== See also == *[[List of Turkish Belgians]] *[[Belgium–Turkey relations]] *[[Turks in Europe]] *[[Islam in Belgium]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}

Hurst & Co. Publishers|isbn=1-85065-209-0}} *{{citation |last=Gailly|first=A|year=1997|chapter=Turkish Immigrants in Belgium|editor1-last=Al-Issa|editor1-first=Ihsan|editor2-last=Tousignant|editor2-first=Michel Turkey|place=|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-62096-1}}. *{{citation|last1=Kaya|first1=Ayhan|last2=Kentel|first2=Ferhat|year=2007|title=Belgian-Turks A Bridge or a Breach between Turkey and the European Union?|url=http://www.kbs-frb.be/uploadedFiles/KBS-FRB/05)_Pictures,_documents_and_external_sites/09)_Publications/%20KBS%E2%80%A2Belgian-Turks%20GB_All%20in(1).pdf|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080626010313/http://www.kbs-frb.be/uploadedFiles/KBS-FRB/05)_Pictures,_documents_and_external_sites/09)_Publications/%20KBS%E2%80%A2Belgian-Turks%20GB_All%20in(1).pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-06-26|publisher=King Baudouin Foundation|isbn=978-90-5130-587-6}} *{{citation|last=King Baudouin Foundation|year=2008|title=Turkish communities and the EU|url=http://www.kbs-frb.be/uploadedFiles/KBS-FRB/18)_Website_static_Content/Enews/International_newsletter_7_(May_2008).pdf|publisher=King Baudouin Foundation|issue=Spring/Summer 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090225081535/http://www.kbs-frb.be/uploadedFiles/KBS-FRB/18)_Website_static_Content/Enews/International_newsletter_7_(May_2008).pdf|archivedate=2009-02-25|df=}} *{{citation |last1=Koutroubas|first1=Theodoros|last2=Vloeberghs|first2=Ward|last3=Yanasmayan|first3=Zeynep|year=2009|chapter=Political, Religious and Ethnic Radicalisation Among Muslims in Belgium|editor1-last=Emerson|editor1-first=Michael|editor2-last=Roy|editor2-first=Olivier (eds.)|title=Ethno-Religious Conflict in Europe: Typologies of Radicalisation in Europe's Muslim Communities|place=|publisher=CEPS|isbn=929079822X}} *{{citation |last=Levinson|first=David|year=1998|title=Ethnic Groups Worldwide: A Ready Reference Handbook|place=|publisher=Greenwood Publishing
